Three-dimensional, mesoporous titanosilicates as catalysts for producing biodiesel and biolubricants Mehejabeen Kotwal Anuj Kumar Srinivas Darbha ⁎ Catalysis Division, National Chemical Laboratory, Pune 411008, India Catalysis Division, National Chemical Laboratory Pune 411008 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 20 2590 2018; fax: +91 20 2590 2633. Graphical abstract The application of three-dimensional, mesoporous titanosilicates, Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16, as reusable solid acid catalysts for producing biodiesel and biolubricants is reported for the first time. Biodiesel was prepared by esterification of oleic acid with monohydric methanol and biolubricants by esterification with polyhydric alcohols (glycerol, trimethylolpropane, neopentyl glycol and pentaerythritol). High catalytic activity of these catalysts is attributed to the presence of dispersed Lewis acidic Ti sites and mesoporosity in the structure. Biodiesel yields as high as 90mol% were obtained at 443K. Surface hydrophobicity of the catalyst has also a predominant role, especially, in reactions involving polyhydric alcohols. In those reactions, Ti-SBA-16 showed higher catalytic activity than Ti-SBA-12. Keywords Titanosilicates Mesoporous materials Ti-SBA-12 Ti-SBA-16 Biodiesel Lubricant basestocks Esterification of fatty acid 1 Introduction In recent times, biomass derived renewable fuels and chemicals have been gaining prominent importance, as fossil fuel resources, the conventional source of energy, are depleting at a faster rate [1,2]. Biodiesel which is a synonym for fatty acid methyl or ethyl esters, produced through transesterification of vegetable oils or animal fat with alcohol, is a sustainable and biodegradable diesel fuel extender [3–7]. The toxic emissions from vehicles using such biofuels are significantly lower than those produced by using fossil fuels [1]. The conventional technology of their production using homogeneous alkali base or mineral acid catalysts is not eco-friendly. Replacement of homogeneous catalysts by solid catalysts makes the process sustainable [8–10]. Use of acid oil (generated in vegetable oil refining process) instead of expensive edible oils makes the biofuels manufacturing process economical [1,2]. Polyol esters of fatty acids are valuable chemical compounds that find application in pharmaceuticals, food and cosmetics production [2]. They are also used as raw material for emulsifiers, surfactants and lubricants [11,12]. Worldwide, the lubricant demand in 2010 was about 36.7 million metric tons [2–4]. Out of that, about 53% is collected as waste, thus endangering our planet. Use of rapidly degradable lubricants instead of the conventional petroleum-derived lubricants could significantly reduce the environmental pollution. The bio-based lubricants have several advantages [2,13]. They are biodegradable and renewable. They possess excellent lubricity. Their friction coefficient is lower than that of mineral oils. They have lower evaporation (up to 20% lesser than mineral oils). Their higher flash point reduces the risk of fires in applications such as metal cutting. Finally, they possess higher viscosity indices. However, there are some issues related to their thermal and oxidation stability, poor low-temperature fluidity and hydrolytic instability that restrict their widespread use. But then, these shortcomings can be overcome by using chemically modified vegetable oils in combination with available additives (antioxidants, pour point depressants) and diluents or functional fluids. Cost-effective production is one the challenging tasks for their extensive use. Their manufacture using solid catalysts is expected to lower the production cost [14–21]. Base catalysts cannot be used for fatty acid esterification due to the deactivation and soap formation. Several solid acid catalysts including WO3/AlPO4, WO3/ZrO2, silica-bonded N-propyl sulfamic acid, silica-supported tin oxide, sulfated-zirconia/titania/tin oxide, sulfonic acid/SBA-15, H3PW12O40 supported on ZrO2 and Ta2O5, sulfonated-C and Nb2O5-MCM-41 have been reported for reactions of fatty compounds with short chain alcohols [22–26]. Their application for biolubricants production using polyhydric alcohols is scarce. Zeolites have attracted great attention in the field of catalysis due to their unique pore structure, high surface area and high stability [27]. However, these materials present severe limitations when large reactant molecules like fatty compounds are employed. Greater attention is being paid to use mesoporous solids instead of zeolites to overcome the above limitation [28–30]. Development of catalysts which are stable and do not leach out during reactions with fatty acids is highly challenging. In this study, we have chosen oleic acid (OA) as a representative fatty acid and methanol (for producing biodiesel) and glycerol, trimethylolpropane, neopentyl glycol and pentaerythritol as representative polyols (for producing biolubricants or surfactants). The application of three-dimensional mesoporous titanosilicates, Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 for producing these industrial oleochemicals is reported. Ti incorporation in the framework of silica generates Lewis acid sites which are active for this reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 materials were prepared using Brij-76 [C18H37(OCH2CH2)10OH, mol. wt. ∼711; Aldrich Co.] and Pluronic F127 block-copolymer (EO106PO70EO106, mol. wt. 12,600; Aldrich Co.) as structure directing agents, respectively. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%; Aldrich Co.) was used as a Si source and titanium isopropoxide (Spectrochem. Pvt. Ltd., India, 98%) was used as a Ti source. All the solvents (A.R. grade) were procured from Thomas Baker and the reagents were purchased from Aldrich Co. SBA-12, SBA-16, Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 were prepared as reported by us earlier [31–33]. There are already a few reports on the preparation of Ti-SBA-16, but the procedure adopted in the present work (direct synthesis) is not the same as reported by others [34–36]. In our method of preparation, the Ti ions are located mainly in the framework and possess a pseudo-tetrahedral geometry. 2.2 Characterization techniques X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the SBA were recorded on a PANalytical (X’pert Pro) diffractometer equipped with a Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation (λ =0.15418nm, 40kV and 30mA) and a proportional counter detector. The diffraction patterns were recorded in the 2θ range of 0.5–5° with a scan rate of 0.2°/min. Those in the high 2θ region (10–80°) were recorded at a rate of 4°/min and with a step size of 0.02°. The N2 adsorption–desorption measurements at 77K were carried out on a Quanta Chrome, USA (Autosorb-1C) equipment. Prior to N2 adsorption, the samples were evacuated at 573K for 5h. The specific surface area of the samples was determined by the Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) method using data points in the relative pressure (P/P 0) region of 0.05–0.3. The total pore volume was determined from the uptake of adsorbate at a relative pressure (P/P 0) of 0.99. A reference alumina sample (Quanta Chrome, USA) was used for calibrating the instrument. The average pore diameter was estimated from the desorption-branch of the isotherms and by using the Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of the samples as KBr pellets (1wt%) were measured in the wavenumber region of 400–4000cm−1 (spectral resolution=4cm−1) using a Shimadzu 8300 spectrophotomer. Diffuse reflectance UV–visible (DRUV–vis) spectral measurements were conducted on a Shimadzu UV-2550 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere attachment (ISR 2200). Spectral grade BaSO4 was used as a reference material. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD; Micromeritics Auto Chem 2910 instrument) quantified the density of acid sites. In a typical experiment, 0.1g of catalyst was taken in a U-shaped, flow-through, quartz sample tube. Prior to measurements, the catalyst was pretreated in He (30mL/min) at 823K for 1h. A mixture of NH3 in He (10 v%) was passed (30mL/min) at 298K for 1h. Then, the sample was, subsequently flushed with He (30mL/min) at 373K for 1h. TPD measurements were carried out in the range 373–1073K at a heating rate of 10K/min. Ammonia concentration in the effluent was monitored with a gold-plated, filament thermal conductivity detector. The amount of desorbed ammonia was determined based on the area under the peak. 2.3 Reaction procedure In the reaction of oleic acid (OA) with methanol, 0.15g of catalyst, 17.7mmol of OA (5g) and methanol (with OA:methanol molar ratio=1:10) were taken in a Teflon-lined, stainless-steel autoclave (100mL) mounted on a rotating hydrothermal reactor (Hiro Co., Japan). The temperature was raised to a desired value (413–443K) and the reactions were conducted at autogeneous pressure for a period of 0.4–8h. At the end of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to 298K and the catalyst was separated by filtration. Methanol from the reaction mixture was removed using a rotary evaporator. Acid values of the reaction mixture at the beginning and end of the reaction were determined by titration method. In a typical titration, 0.5g of OA or the final product was weighed with an accuracy of 0.001g and dissolved in 25mL of a neutral solvent mixture (isopropyl alcohol and toluene in equal volume) taken in a 250mL conical flask. Three to five drops of phenolphthalein indicator (1%, Merck, India) were added to it. Then the solution was titrated against 0.1N standardized NaOH solution till a colorless to pink end-point was achieved. These titrations were done three times and the average value was considered to evaluate the acid value of the material. NaOH (0.1N) was standardized using 0.1N oxalic acid solution. The equations employed for determining the acid value and OA conversion are given below. Acid value = 56.1 × N V W OA content in the sample ( mol % ) = N × V × 282.47 W × 10 , OA conversion ( mol % ) = 100 − OA content in the sample Here, 56.1 is the molecular weight of KOH, as acid value is conventionally reported as mg of KOH per g of sample, W is the weight of the sample in grams, N is the normality of sodium hydroxide solution and V is the volume of sodium hydroxide solution (mL). All the esterification reactions with polyols were performed in a glass batch reactor placed in a temperature-controlled oil bath and fitted with a water-cooled condenser. In a typical reaction, a known quantity of OA (4–9g), polyol (OA:polyol molar ratio varying between 3:1 and 1:4) and catalyst (3wt% of OA) were taken and the reaction was conducted at 453K and atmospheric pressure for a period of 1–10h. At the end of the reaction, the catalyst was separated and the liquid portion was analyzed for mono- and polyglycerides composition using a Perkin-Elmer (Series 200) high performance liquid chromatograph (HPLC) equipped with an ELSD detector (Gilson) and a reverse-phase Perkin-Elmer Brownlee column (C-18 Spheri-5, 250mm×4.6mm with a 5μm particle size). Acid value was determined by the above described titrimetric method. Fatty acid conversions were monitored also by 1H NMR and HPLC methods. The results obtained by all these methods were comparable. However, for convenience and its high accuracy, only the values obtained from the titrimetric method are reported in this study. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characterization A detailed characterization of Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 samples was reported by us earlier [32,33]. For the sake of completeness, we present here, in brevity, some pertinent physicochemical characteristic features of these catalyst materials. The XRD patterns of SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-12 were consistent with a three-dimensional, hexagonal mesopore ordering and indexed to a space group of p63/mmc. Those of SBA-16 and Ti-SBA-16 were corresponded to a three-dimensional cubic mesopore structure with a space group of Im 3 ¯ m [33]. The unit cell parameters (a and c for hexagonal SBA-12 and a for cubic SBA-16) increased with increasing titanium content in the structure and indicated isomorphous substitution of Ti4+ for Si4+ in the mesoporous silica framework location [31,32]. DRUV–vis spectroscopy differentiated various structural types of Ti showing characteristic ligand to metal charge transfer bands at 210nm for tetrapodal Ti [Ti(OSi)4], 217–220nm for tripodal Ti [Ti(OSi)3(OH)] and 315nm for octahedral anatase type Ti species [33]. From spectral deconvolution, the concentration of tetrapodal Ti was determined. The ordered mesopore structure in these catalysts was confirmed further by high resolution transmission electron microscopy and N2 physisorption studies [33]. Table 1 presents the composition of total Ti (Si/Ti estimated using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy), percentage tetrahedral Ti (estimated from DRUV–vis data) and textural properties of these catalysts. Acidic properties of these catalysts were determined using pyridine and ammonia as probe molecules [33]. Diffuse reflectance infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine revealed the presence of Lewis-type acid sites. The density of acid sites was determined (from temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia studies; NH3-TPD) and listed in Table 1. SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-12 showed 29Si magic angle spin nuclear magnetic resonance (29Si MAS NMR) signals at −91.8, −100.9 and −110.6ppm, corresponding to presence of three different types of silica species, Q2, Q3 and Q4. SBA-16 and Ti-SBA-16 showed two signals at −98.1 and −108.5ppm attributable to Q3 and Q4 type silica species, respectively [33]. The downfield shift of Q3 and Q4 signals in the case of Ti-SBA-16 has been attributed to differences in the structures of Ti-SBA-16 compared to Ti-SBA-12. Spectral deconvolutions revealed that the signal intensity ratio of Q4/(Q3 +Q2), a representative of surface hydrophobicity, is one order of magnitude higher for SBA-16 than for SBA-12 material. In other words, SBA-16 materials were found to be relatively more hydrophobic than SBA-12 [33]. This conclusion was confirmed further from the thermogravimetric studies of the calcined samples [33]. The characterization studies revealed that the titanosilicates of the present study have (1) Ti ions isolated and substituted for silicon in the framework possessing tetracoordinated geometry, (2) ordered mesoporosity, (3) Lewis acidity and (4) varying hydrophobic surface structure. All these features are expected to have strong and positive bearing on their catalytic activity for them to be superior to microporous TS-1 in the reactions involving bulky fatty acid molecules. 3.2 Catalytic activity studies 3.2.1 Esterification of OA with methanol Oleic acid (OA; C18.1) with eighteen carbon atoms and one double bond between C9 and C10 carbon atoms is a major constituent of several vegetable oils including soybean, rapeseed and corn. So it was considered in this study as a representative fatty acid present in edible and non-edible vegetable oils. Esterification of OA with methanol (a monohydric alcohol) results in methyl oleate ester which is a suitable substitute for the conventional petroleum diesel. Methyl oleate has lower cold flow properties than palmitate (C16.0) and stearate (C18.0) esters and better oxidation stability than linoleic (C18.2) and linolenic (C18.3) esters [1]. The esterification reaction of OA with methanol (Eq. (1)) produces water as by-product. Most of the acid catalysts get destabilized in the presence of water and cannot be reused in a long run [10,22–26]. In this section, we have examined the catalytic performance of Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 for this reaction. The effect of Ti content in these SBA catalysts on esterification activity has been examined. (1) Oleicacid+Methanol↔Methyloleate+Water Table 2 presents catalytic activity data of Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 with varying Si/Ti molar ratio for the esterification of OA with methanol at 443K for 1h. The reaction occurs even without a catalyst at our experimental conditions. However, OA conversion was 16mol% only. No significant improvement in OA conversion was found when the reaction was carried out in the presence of all silica SBA-12 and SBA-16 (Table 2; entry nos. 1 and 7). This suggests that silanol groups on these silica materials are not catalytically active. A marked increase in OA conversion was observed when the reaction was performed in the presence of titanium-containing SBA-12 and SBA-16 (Table 2). OA conversion increased from 16.1 (without any catalyst) to 29.2 [with Ti-SBA-16(50); Table 2, entry no. 9] and 41.2mol% [with Ti-SBA-12(40); Table 2, entry no. 4]. Ti-SBA-12 was relatively more active than Ti-SBA-16. This study, thus, reveals that Lewis acidic Ti ions are the active sites in mesoporous titanosilicate catalysts, Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16. The intrinsic catalytic activity (turnover frequency, TOF) was calculated based on total amount of Ti present in the catalyst, Ti present exclusively in framework locations as tetrahedral sites and acidity estimated from NH3-TPD measurements. In general, TOF values estimated based on acidity of the catalysts were found higher than those calculated using the Ti content (Table 2). Further, the values estimated based on framework Ti were higher than those based on total amount of Ti. This is because there exits some extraframework Ti species in the catalysts which do not contribute to the activity. The intrinsic catalytic activity of Ti (TOF values) decreased with decrease in Si/Ti molar ratio revealing that not all Ti ions in titanosilicate catalysts have the same activity. Their intrinsic activity decreased with increasing Ti content in the catalyst sample. We believe that TOF values estimated based on acidity of the catalyst are more accurate than the other methods of estimation. However, it may be noted that the best conversion and the highest TOF do not correspond to the most acidic materials. This discrepancy indicates that other than acid site density, the strength of acid sites also plays an important role. Ti-SBA-12 having large pore diameter, specific surface area and pore volume than Ti-SBA-16 (Table 1) showed higher catalytic activity (conversion and TOF) for esterification of OA with methanol. This is possibly due to more facile diffusion of fatty acid molecules inside the mesoporous silica matrix and accessibility of all the active Ti sites inside the pores. Neat anatase titania (TiO2) and microporous TS-1 were not active for this reaction. Only the dispersed and framework substituted, tetracoordinated Ti sites and the mesoporous architecture facilitate the catalytic esterification reaction. Also experiments were conducted under the same conditions using SBA-15, Ti-SBA-15 and Ti-MCM-41 as catalysts [OA=5g, OA:methanol (molar ratio)=1:10, catalyst=3wt% of OA, reaction temperature=443K, reaction time=1h]. While Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 belong to the class of three-dimensional mesoporous materials, SBA-15 and MCM-41 exhibit well-defined hexagonal two-dimensional pore network. OA conversions of 15.9, 19.2 and 17.3mol% were observed with SBA-15, Ti-SBA-15 and Ti-MCM-41 catalysts, respectively. This study thus confirms that the three-dimensional mesoporous architecture of Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 enables facile diffusion of bulky molecules and improves accessibility of active sites and thereby the enhanced catalytic activity for esterification reactions compared to the two-dimensional Ti-MCM-41 and Ti-SBA-15 materials. Diffusion tests were conducted in a different 100mL stainless steel Paar high pressure reactor (Parr 4871), where the mode of stirring was along the axis of the reactor. Note that, all the other reactions were conducted in a Hiro Co., reactor where the mode of stirring was horizontal (i.e., perpendicular to the axis of the reactor). Reactions in the Paar reactor were performed using Ti-SBA-16(80) as the catalyst and taking a catalyst amount of 0.15g, oleic acid of 5g and oleic acid:methanol (molar ratio) of 1:30; reaction time was 1h and reaction temperature was 443K. The tests were conducted at different stirring speeds (50–600rpm). A marginal increase in OA conversion from 52.0 (at 50rpm) to 55.7 (at 100rpm), 58.0 (at 400rpm) and 57.8mol% (at 600rpm) was observed indicating that internal diffusion is not an issue with this catalyst system. Reactions were conducted at four different temperatures (413, 423, 433 and 443K). Conversion of OA was monitored as a function of time (Fig. 1 ). They increased with increasing reaction time and temperature. At 443K, about 90mol% of OA got converted to its methyl ester when the reaction was carried out for 8h. From the conversion versus time plots, the initial rates of reaction at different temperatures were determined. Then, the rate constant (k) was calculated using the pseudo-first order rate law. Note that methanol was taken in excess in all these reactions (OA:methanol molar ratio=1:10). Employing the Arrhenius equation, activation energy values (E a) were determined (Fig. 1). The E a values for Ti-SBA-12(40) and Ti-SBA-16(50) were estimated to be 42.7 and 25.6kJ/mol, respectively. Detailed characterization studies (thermal analysis and 29Si MAS NMR) reported by us earlier [34] revealed that Ti-SBA-16 is relatively more hydrophobic than Ti-SBA-12. Hence, the byproduct water generated in the esterification reaction (Eq. (1)) does not compete for adsorption with the reactants on Ti-SBA-16 surface and thereby, lowers the activation energy compared to that for Ti-SBA-12. The E a value of 25.6kJ/mol for Ti-SBA-16(50) is close to the diffusion limitation value. Any internal mass transfer control issue could be addressed through Koros–Nowak test [37]. In this test, catalysts with different active site loadings would be prepared and the rate per active site is plotted. If this value is found independent of the concentration, then, the reaction is not diffusion controlled. We have determined the rates of OA esterification reaction with methanol for Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 catalysts with different Ti loadings. The reactions were conducted at 443K and for 2h. As seen from Fig. 2 (a) and (b), rate per unit amount of total Ti or tetrahedral Ti decreased with increasing amount of Ti concentration. As esterification is an acid catalyzed reaction, we have also plotted the rate per unit acidity with the acid site concentration in the catalysts (Fig. 2(c)). In all these instances, a decrease in the rate with an increase in the amount of Ti content and acid site density was noted. These observations suggest that this reaction is under diffusion controlled limit. However, it may be noted that the textural properties of these mesoporous catalysts are nearly the same for all the catalysts investigated (Table 1) and the pore size is large enough for facile penetration of fatty acid molecules. According to single crystal X-ray structure, the β-form of oleic acid has dimensions of 1.97nm×0.44nm [37] and the low melting form of oleic acid has dimensions of 1.778nm×0.59nm [38]. Average pore size of Ti-SBA-12 catalyst is in the range 5–5.5nm and of Ti-SBA-16 is in the range 3.4–4nm. Hence, internal diffusion of OA inside the pore of Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 is not an issue. When we plotted the acidity of the catalysts per unit Ti as a function of total Ti content, we observed the same behavior as above, i.e., acidity per Ti site decreases with increasing Ti content in the catalyst. This suggests that not all Ti ions in Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16 with different Si/Ti molar ratios have the same acidic properties. Ti is known to be present as framework tetrahedral Ti species and extra-framework penta- or hexacoordinated species. Further, within tetrahedral species, they present as tetrapodal [Ti(OSi)4] or tripodal [Ti(OH)(OSi)3] species. All these different structural Ti species lead to sites with varying acidity and reactivity. In view of this, we believe that the Koros–Nowak test [39] is not passed in cases where such non-uniform active sites are present in the catalysts. As the pore size is large and the catalyst material has high surface area and pore volume, we believe that diffusion control is not an issue in the present case and the observed lower E a value for Ti-SBA-16 is due to its hydrophobic surface only. The enhanced utility of the present catalysts is actually due to access of the catalytic sites. We have carried out the esterification as a function of time without a catalyst at 443K taking 5g of OA and 10 times molar excess of methanol. Conversion of OA increased from 16.1mol% in 1h to 65.1mol% in 8h. In the presence of Ti-SBA-12(40) and Ti-SBA-16(50), this conversion of OA in 8h was 87.5 and 87.7mol%, respectively. Thus, this study reveals that there is some contribution also from the non-catalytic component. Reusability of the catalysts was investigated in four recycling experiments. After each reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration, washed with methanol, dried at 373K for 3h and then reused in the subsequent recycle. As seen from Fig. 3 , the esterification activities (OA conversion) of both Ti-SBA-12(40) and Ti-SBA-16(50) were almost the same in all the four recycling experiments. The catalysts after the 3rd recycle were subjected to XRD and FTIR analyses. As seen from Fig. 4 , the crystal structure (XRD) of the catalyst is intact and no accumulation of organic matter (acid/ester/alcohol) was detected in the FTIR spectrum of the reused catalyst. The Si/Ti ratios of the fresh and spent catalysts were the same (ICP-OES) and the liquid product did not contain any Ti ions. These observations indicate no leaching of Ti ions from the solid catalyst during the reactions. 3.2.2 Esterification of OA with glycerol The reaction of OA with glycerol (G) yields mono-, di- and triglyceride esters (ME, DE and TE, respectively; Scheme 1 ). Variation in their composition generates lubricant chemicals with varied properties. The composition of the glyceride esters in the product can be controlled or varied by changing OA to polyol molar ratio, temperature, reaction time and type of catalyst used. Glyceride esters were synthesized using the best performed titanosilicates, Ti-SBA-12(40) and Ti-SBA-16(50) as catalysts. Esterification of OA with glycerol was carried out at 453K for 3h taking OA and G in the molar ratio of 3:1, 1:1, 1:2, 1:3 and 1:4. Catalyst with 3wt% of OA was used. OA conversion and turnover frequency for consuming OA in the formation of mono-, di- and triglyceride esters increased with increasing amounts of glycerol (Table 3 ). As observed in the earlier section, TOF values calculated based on acidity of the catalyst were higher than those estimated based on total and framework substituted Ti ions. As stated before, TOF determination based on acidity is more accurate method than on the Ti content. Contrary to the observations in reactions with monohydric methanol, Ti-SBA-16(50) in reactions with polyhydric glycerol showed higher catalytic activity (OA conversion and TOF) than Ti-SBA-12(40). The esters selectivity is nearly the same over both these titanosilicate catalysts. Glycerol is more hydrophilic than methanol. Its conversion over hydrophobic Ti-SBA-16(50) is expected to be more than that on relatively more hydrophilic Ti-SBA-12(40). This importance of surface structure in esterification reaction is more obvious only when the alcohol is changed from methanol to glycerol. In other words, the study with glycerol demonstrates that not only the Lewis acid Ti sites but also the surface structure is equally important in esterification reaction with polyhydric alcohols. Hydrophillic glycerol sticks strongly on hydrophilic surfaces and thereby, leads to lower conversions on such catalyst surfaces. Reaction temperature has a significant effect on the esterification reaction (Fig. 5 ). OA conversion increased with increase in temperature from 393 to 473K. Formation of triglyceride ester (TE) was observed only above 433K. The concentration of di- and triglycerides (DE+TE) increased and monoglyceride (ME) decreased with an increase in temperature. These observations were similar for both Ti-SBA-12(40) and Ti-SBA-16(50). OA conversion as high as 80mol% with ME selectivity of 60% and DE+TE selectivity of 40% was observed at 473K. The amount of catalyst has also influenced the reaction. OA conversion increased linearly (from 23 to 60mol% for Ti-SBA-12(40) and from 30 to 65mol% for Ti-SBA-16(50)) with an increase in catalyst amount from 1 to 7wt% (Fig. 6 ). 3.2.3 Esterification of oleic acid with different polyols Having noted the efficiency of Ti-SBA-12(40) and Ti-SBA-16(50) catalysts for the reactions of OA with methanol and glycerol, the studies were extended to esterifications with other useful polyhydric alcohols viz., trimethylolpropane (TMP), neopentylglycol (NPG) and pentaerythritol (PE) (Table 4 ). Replacement of β proton in glycerol with an alkyl substituent as is the case in trimethylolpropane results in thermally more stable polyol esters [12]. The reactions were carried out at 453K for 1h with OA:polyol molar ratio of 1:1. These titanosilicates have been found to be highly active even in these reactions. At our reaction conditions, OA conversion with different polyols decreased in the order: TMP>NPG>G>PE. While TMP and G have three hydroxyl groups resulting in mono-, di- and trimesters (ME, DE and TE), NPG has only two hydroxyl groups and yields ME and DE. PE has four hydroxyl groups and is less active compared to the other polyols perhaps due to its high melting point (533K). Formation of a significant amount of di- and triesters (DE and TE; selectivity∼98%) was noted when the reaction was conducted with OA:TMP molar ratio of 3:1 and for a reaction time of 10h. A similar observation was found also for glycerol (DE+TE; selectivity∼65%). By and large, the present study reveals that the mesoporous titanosilicate catalysts of the present study are highly active for esterification of OA with a range of mono and polyhydric alcohols producing baseoil feedstocks for biodiesel and biolubricant applications. Other than acidity (due to dispersed tetrahedral Ti ions), pore diameter, pore volume and surface hydrophobicity control the OA conversion toward formation of synthetic esters. Contrary to OA esterification with methanol, the most active catalyst in reactions involving glycerol is Ti-SBA-16 although it exhibits less facile diffusion. However, for more bulky glycerol the diffusion should be an important factor. In spite of that, Ti-SBA-16 exhibited superior activity to Ti-SBA-12 in the esterification of OA with glycerol and other polyols. Glycerol being more hydrophilic molecule adheres more strongly on hydrophilic catalyst surfaces and hinders the activation of hydrophobic OA molecules and their further reaction. Hence, a hydrophobic catalyst would perform better in such esterification reactions with polyols. To establish this further, we have added water to the reaction medium and the OA+methanol esterification was conducted at 443K for 1h. Conversion of OA was not affected when 3mmol of water was added. However, when 8mmol of water (i.e., about 50mol% of OA) was added, OA conversion decreased by 67mol% for Ti-SBA-12(40) catalyst. This decrease in OA conversion was only 61mol% for Ti-SBA-16(50). In other words, surface hydrophobicity plays an important role in esterification reactions with polyols. Accordingly to Bondioli [14], powdered metallic zinc and tin(II) oxide are the two catalysts currently available at an industrially reasonable price for the preparation of polyesters of fatty acids. However, only 90–95% of the catalyst could be recovered by simple filtration. Highly efficient purification procedures are needed because of the tendency of the catalyst to form metallic soaps of fatty acids. The latter are soluble in esters and may negatively affect the performance of the final product, in terms of its oxidative, thermal and hydrolytic stability. Recently, Masood et al. [15] reported the application of calcium methoxide as heterogeneous catalyst for these reactions. Moisture sensitivity is one of the issues with this catalyst. The mesoporous titanosilicate catalysts of the present study are moisture and air insensitive and could be recovered easily without any issue unlike the prior art catalysts for lubricant base oil production. 4 Conclusions The application of three-dimensional, mesoporous titanosilicates (Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16) for the esterification of OA with (1) monohydric methanol and (2) polyhydric alcohols viz., glycerol, trimethylolpropane, neopentylglycol and pentaerythritol was investigated producing synthetic esters suitable for biodiesel and biolubricant applications, respectively. Biodiesel yields as high as 90mol% were obtained at 443K. The titanosilicate catalysts were reusable and highly active for these reactions. Dispersed tetrahedral Ti ions are the acid sites catalyzing the esterification reaction. While Ti-SBA-12(40) is the most efficient catalyst for the reaction of OA with methanol, Ti-SBA-16(50) was found superior in the esterification with polyhydric alcohols producing biolubricants. Ti-SBA-16 is relatively more hydrophobic than Ti-SBA-12. At OA:TMP molar ratio of 3:1 and at 453K and 10h of reaction, OA conversion as high as 85.6mol% and di-+triester selectivity of 98.6mol% was obtained over Ti-SBA-16(50) catalyst. To the best of our knowledge, this is the highest per pass polyester yield obtained so far over solid catalyst. The present study with polyhydric alcohols clearly demonstrated the importance of surface hydrophobicity of catalyst in esterification reactions. Higher surface area, pore volume, Lewis acidity and hydrophobicity are the factors responsible for the superior catalytic activity of these catalysts in esterification reactions. coredata.dc:description: The application of three-dimensional, mesoporous titanosilicates, Ti-SBA-12 and Ti-SBA-16, as reusable solid acid catalysts for producing biodiesel and biolubricants is reported for the first time. Biodiesel was prepared by esterification of oleic acid with monohydric methanol and biolubricants by esterification with polyhydric alcohols (glycerol, trimethylolpropane, neopentyl glycol and pentaerythritol). High catalytic activity of these catalysts is attributed to the presence of dispersed Lewis acidic Ti sites and mesoporosity in the structure. Biodiesel yields as high as 90mol% were obtained at 443K. Surface hydrophobicity of the catalyst has also a predominant role, especially, in reactions involving polyhydric alcohols. In those reactions, Ti-SBA-16 showed higher catalytic activity than Ti-SBA-12.
coredata.dc:title: Three-dimensional, mesoporous titanosilicates as catalysts for producing biodiesel and biolubricants
